messageBody:
On Thursday 07 August 2003 18:25, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> I have just built ParameterizedTestSuite, which allows you to automatically
> build a suite of tests (from test* methods), but pass parameters to the
> underlying test fixture.

I didn't see this fly by, so [now the Release Pressure has dropped on our
system] I'm having a go myself. It's not very general, but here's what I've
got/done, and a Question:

* AbstractTestGraph is the class [subclass, eventually, of TestCase] of
tests for Graph; subclasses must define getGraph() to return the Graph
to be tested.

* There are three styles of Graph, so each new implementation of Graph at
the moment has to generate three new subclasses of AbstractTestGraph,
one for each style of Graph for getGraph, and suite them up together.
Ikky.

* So experimentally I have MetaTestGraph which subclasses AbstractTestGraph,
with a constructor which takes a [Graph] Class and a Style as well as a
string, passes the String up to the superclass as usual, and remembers
the other two arguments in instance variables.

* MetaTestGraph's getGraph uses reflection to invoke the remembered Class's
constructor which takes a Style argument.

* MetaTestGraph has a suite(Class,Style) method which gets the test methods
out of AbstractTestGraph and adds them to its TestSuite result. When
it adds them, of course it can supply the two additional parameters.

* Now other Graph implementations can have suite()s which include
MetaTestGraph.suite(MyMarvelousNewGraph.class, someStyle)

I am about to try this out for real ... I can post the code if necessary,
we're an open-source project. If anyone has any simplifications, warnings,
whatever, let me know.

And the Question is, why are TestSuite::isPublicTestMethod and
TestSuite::isTestMethod *private*? Because even if I wrote a subclass
of TestSuite, rather than using methods in MetaTestGraph, I wouldn't
be able to re-use them ...
